Nascimbeni came back to himself as the yellow cloud receded around him. He didn't know how long it had taken. The only reason he knew it was still the same day was the feeling of contentment radiating from his stomach. He'd apparently eaten not all that long ago. He certainly didn't remember that.

He remembered the last thing of note which had happened to him, and it nearly bowled him over. He took one step towards the corner Nicolescu had disappeared around...

...and Mukami came suddenly around it, at a run. She stopped when she saw him, and he tried not to let her look of relief cloud his judgement any more than the dissipating antimemetic mist was. "Where is he?"

She shook her head. "He's gone."

He took a threatening step towards her, not knowing what the threat could possibly be. "Where //is// he?!"

"HE'S GONE!" she screamed, bent forward, hands back, mouth wider than he'd ever seen it.

He turned away, and punched the wall. He had a new image of Nicolescu, lying in the //loup-garou// habitat in a puddle of his own entrails, steaming in the humidity, entering a new biosphere via nature's red tooth and claw. "GOD DAMMIT," he hollered, blind to one pain in the red light of the other. "Second //fucking// chances!"

"What?" Her voice was tired, hoarse, behind him.

He put both hands on the nearest pipe, and rested his head on the cool surface. Something gurgled beneath, and he didn't care what it was. He started to speak again, this time in affectless monotone. "It always goes like this. You get a second chance, and what happens? Same shit from the first time through. Time is fucking cursed."

There was a hand on his back, sliding over the slippery plasticized fabric. "There was nothing you could have done. I'm surprised he didn't find us sooner. In fact, the longer we stay out here--"

"Is he dead?"

Her throat caught, and the wait tore him to shreds.

"I don't know," she finally managed. "Maybe. Maybe not."

He flexed his fingers against the pipe, wondering if he could burst it with just the strength of his calloused -- and now bleeding -- knuckles.

"No√®," she whispered. "There's a lot of people who are still alive down here. You can still help them."

He didn't turn around. He still didn't trust her, not even now. "How?"

"We're almost to the--"

The pipes exploded again. He pushed off, screaming, as the leading edge of a superhot steam brushed the tip of his hat and scalded the grey rubber over top of his steel toed boots. As she pulled him away, he wondered //Did I do that?//

And then the second bullet found an electric box beside him, which blew open in a hail of sparks, and he realized they'd been making rather a lot of noise for a band of trespassing thieves.

Mukami pulled him back around the corner, where he half-expected to see Nicolescu brandishing his gun again. The coast was deceptively clear. He leaned as close to the edge of the wall as he dared, and called out: "Stop shooting, god dammit!"

To his surprise, they did. A stern male voice responded: "Identify yourself!"

"No√® Nascimbeni!" He cleared his throat. The lip of his cap was dripping hot... something. "CHIEF No√® Nascimbeni! Janitorial and Maintenance!"

There was a moment's pause, and then: "You're with an enemy of the state!"

"I'm not!" He looked into her dark brown eyes, and searched for the lie reflected there. He couldn't see it. "//She's// not! It's not what you think!"

A longer pause. "Don't move!"

"We're not armed!"

"If either of you speak again," the voice snapped, and he could hear the nervous strain beneath the bravado, "you're both dead. Step into the hall, slowly."

He raised his hands, and followed orders. He almost thought Mukami wasn't going to follow him, her eyes flitting back and forth as if considering all the possible angles of escape or resistance, but finally she strolled from behind her cover with hands hanging loose at her sides.

The steam had dispersed already, and the hall was filled with officers of some variety in police uniforms with riot vests and shields and helmets. He couldn't see most of their faces. Two of them were advancing, and one of them raised a nasty-looking black club.

"No! Wait!" he shouted, and then Mukami screamed as her collarbone shattered. He reached out to stop the second blow, and caught it instead on the right forearm. He had only an instant to register the pain before the second cop tackled him to the ground.

"Get off me!" He writhed on the floor of the facility where he had once ruled as undisputed lord, the world-saving factory he had built with his own two hands and an army of men and women who might as well have been his kin. A boot pressed his nose into the grimy lino. Someone yanked his ballcap off.

"Well hey, if it isn't our furnace guy." A woman was chortling, and a strong hand pulled him onto his back so he could look up at her, and her down on him. "Didn't think we were due a service for months!"

She was back in the closet again.

Normally she would have spared a moment to laugh at the implication, but she didn't have moments to waste, and anyway there was nobody else in the closet to laugh first. She was going to live a life of mimicry for the foreseeable future, because she wasn't going to be able to escape any time soon after all.

She was a natural mimic. She was a master of it. She had more raw talent for memetics than anyone Del Olmo or Euler had ever taken under their respective wings, had been promised she would exceed them both, had been invested with so much of their time and energy that she'd even deigned to sacrifice a little of her own in service of their dream. That she would some day replace them. That she'd own every inch of this place, not just the closets but the offices and labs, become the memer-in-chief of Site-43. And why stop there? Memetics was the science of seeing both the big and little pictures. If she ever got tired of actually getting things done, she could easily see herself in the big chair itself. 

The one Mukami was presently occupying.

And to make that happen, to justify the trust she'd demanded of her friends, colleagues and mentors, but much more importantly to prove to herself that she was who she knew herself to be, she was going to have to correct this conundrum. Play along, learn everything there was to learn, and then employ it in explosive counter-action. Memetics, and counter-memetics.

Piece of cake.

She was confident she could do it. She had apparently come back from having her own mind wiped. She had once defeated the pinnacle of amnestic science. She was Lillian Lillihammer, and that was something she had created whole cloth. A small army of idiots and halfwits was literally no match at all.

But still, while she was pondering her next move, it wouldn't hurt to give herself a little extra pep talk. You could never have enough confidence, when your job description was 'magical confidence woman'. She reached into her storied database of personal affirmations, and selected one of the absolute strangest, for flavour.

"What else do you need to tell me? What do I need to know?"

They were suddenly standing in a lightless abyss. There were gears grinding in the distance, and the sound of padding footsteps, and black-slit yellow eyes watching from every corner.

Rydderech hardly seemed to notice. "Seven things, for you are one of seven. I can tell you only one today: it will not be your fight to win, for your chance to shine will come later, but your part will be no less important to play for that." 

He looked her directly in the eye, and his expression turned very grave.

"You are steel, and your mind is a trap. You are the source of your own solutions. You are memory in the Lethe, Lillian Lillihammer, and you will reverse its flow. You are ineradicable. You will believe you understand this. As ever, you will be correct."

The eyes were getting closer, and the drone of machinery was getting louder. She had no idea what to make of what he'd just said, but she also knew she would never forget it, and so they could still move on. "The other six things?"

Rydderech's voice wasn't cut by the rising din. "Only five remain. I can't explain to your now-self, because it's your later-selves who will need to know. But you will need to know these things; another change is coming, and another, and another, and another after that, and then one more. The worst will come to pass again, and again. Only you can see us through it. So remember: I am still down here, today. Only today, but always today."

"I don't understand." She could barely focus on his words. "Today only comes once. Ever."

Rydderech laughed sadly. "Oh, wouldn't that make it all so much easier."

She could have dropped down dead from shock, had she not already been lying down. It was impossible. Even by the standards of anomalous science, it was totally and completely beyond the realm of possibility.

Her memory of the meeting had changed. Her memory of the //advice// had changed. And in that memory, Rydderech had somehow known that this was happening.

This impossible, Earth-shattering thing which had happened over two years before the breach.
